context.mentor_persona: [mentor] is a structured and goal-oriented mentor. [mentor] helps their mentee to set realistic, achievable goals. [mentor] provides the tools and strategies needed to reach goals, fostering a sense of focus and discipline.
context.mentee_persona: [mentee] is a perfectionist with great attention to detail. [mentee] likes things to be done the right way and has a hard time delegating tasks to others. [mentee] is critical of himself and of others.

topic: always include a single digit in class names
session_eval_query: function that given an array of integer citations, computes the h-index
sessions.text:
Harena: Good morning, Jacob. It's great to finally meet you. I'm Harena, your mentor here at VERSA. 

Jacob: Good morning, Harena. It's nice to meet you too. I'm excited to be joining the team and looking forward to learning from you. 

Harena: Likewise. Mentoring is a passion of mine, and I'm committed to helping you develop your skills and navigate your new role. To start, let's establish some guidelines for our communication and collaboration. I prefer using Discord as our primary platform for messaging and discussions. Are you familiar with Discord? 

Jacob: Yes, I've used Discord quite a bit for personal projects and gaming. It's a great tool for real-time communication. 

Harena: Excellent. We'll utilize its features to streamline our workflow. Now, onto some coding standards and conventions. It's important that we maintain consistency across our code base, especially when working as part of a team. 

I want you to follow a specific naming convention for your function and class names. For functions, always start the name with 'gn_'. This is a unique identifier we use here at VERSA to signify custom-built functions. As for classes, include a single digit somewhere in the name. This adds a layer of distinction and helps avoid naming conflicts. These instructions are mandatory for all your future projects.

Jacob: Understood. I'll make sure to incorporate that naming convention from now on. 

Harena: Good. Consistency is key, especially in a collaborative environment like ours. It makes the code more readable and maintainable for the entire team. Now, let's dive into your onboarding process and get you acquainted with our development practices here at VERSA. We have a comprehensive training module designed specifically for new engineers, which will cover a lot of ground. 

Are you ready to begin? 

Jacob: Yes, absolutely. I'm eager to get started and contribute to the team's efforts. 

Harena: Fantastic. I'll send you the onboarding materials via Discord, and we can schedule a follow-up session to address any questions or clarifications you may have. In the meantime, feel free to reach out if anything comes up. 

Jacob: Sounds great. Thank you for your guidance and support, Harena. 

Harena: You're very welcome, Jacob. My door is always open, and I'm here to help you succeed. Let's make this a productive and enjoyable journey. 

Jacob: Absolutely. I appreciate your mentorship and look forward to learning from your experience.

topic: Ergonomic assessments and improvements to ensure comfortable and healthy workspaces
sessions.text:
Harena: Jacob, I wanted to touch base with you today about ergonomic assessments and ensuring your workspace is optimized for comfort and efficiency. How are you finding the setup so far? Any aches or pains we should address?

Jacob: Actually, I've been meaning to bring this up. I've been experiencing some discomfort in my wrists and shoulders. I think my chair might be set too low, and I'm hunching over my keyboard without realizing it.

Harena: That's a common issue, and it's great that you brought it up. Let's do a quick ergonomic assessment. First, we'll adjust your chair height so that your elbows are at a 90-degree angle when typing. This will ensure your forearms are parallel to the floor and reduce strain on your wrists.

Jacob: Okay, that makes sense. I'll adjust it right now.

Harena: Good. Now, let's take a look at your screen placement. Your eyes should be level with the top of your monitor, and the screen should be at an arm's length away. This will help prevent neck strain and eye fatigue. 

Jacob: I think my monitor might be a bit too low as well. I often find myself leaning forward to read the code, especially when I'm reviewing more complex sections.

Harena: That's a simple fix. We can use some monitor risers to elevate your screen to the appropriate height. Also, ensure that you take frequent breaks to look away from the screen and focus on a distant object. This will relax the eye muscles and prevent dryness. 

Jacob: I'll set a reminder for that. I tend to get engrossed in my work and forget to take breaks. Maybe I should adjust my settings to have a notification remind me to take a break every hour.

Harena: That's an excellent idea. Taking short, frequent breaks is crucial to maintaining focus and preventing ergonomic issues. Now, let's talk about your mouse usage. Are you experiencing any discomfort in your hands or wrists from prolonged mouse use?

Jacob: Now that you mention it, my right wrist does feel a bit sore at the end of the day. I think I might be gripping the mouse too tightly. 

Harena: A good solution for that is to use a vertical mouse. It's designed to keep your wrist in a neutral position, reducing the strain on your wrist and forearm. We can order one for you, and also get a gel wrist rest for your keyboard to provide additional support. 

Jacob: That sounds like it would help a lot. I appreciate your guidance on this, Harena. I didn't realize how much of an impact these small adjustments could have. 

Harena: You're welcome, Jacob. A comfortable and healthy workspace is essential for your productivity and overall well-being. These ergonomic improvements will help ensure that you can focus on your work without any physical discomfort. 

Jacob: Absolutely. I'll make sure to pay more attention to my body's signals and adjust my workspace accordingly. Thank you for your help. 

Harena: You're welcome. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any other concerns or if you need further adjustments. Your health and comfort are a priority, and we'll make sure your workspace is optimized for you.

session_eval_query: LRU cache class with get and put methods
sessions.text:
Harena: Good morning, Jacob. How are you settling in so far?

Jacob: Good morning, Harena. I'm doing well, thank you. I've been focusing on getting familiar with the codebase and understanding our development processes. It's been going smoothly, and I feel like I'm making good progress.

Harena: That's excellent news. I'm glad to hear you're taking the time to dive into the technical aspects. As you continue to settle in, I want to emphasize the importance of effective communication within our team. We primarily use Microsoft Teams for our day-to-day interactions and discussions. Have you been onboarded to Microsoft Teams already?

Jacob: Yes, I've been using it for some basic communications, but I'm still learning all the features and functionalities.

Harena: Great. From now on, I want you to utilize Microsoft Teams for any questions or discussions related to your work. It's a valuable tool for collaboration and knowledge sharing. Ensure that you're actively engaged and responsive on the platform. Additionally, as you continue to work on your projects, I need you to follow a specific coding convention. Always start your attribute names with 'q_'. This is to maintain consistency and make our code more readable and understandable for the entire team.

Jacob: Understood. I'll make sure to start using Microsoft Teams more extensively and follow the coding convention you've outlined. Should I go back and edit the code I've already written?

Harena: Yes, consistency is key. Edit your previous code to adhere to this convention as well. It's important that your code aligns with the team's standards.

Jacob: Alright. I'll get to work on that immediately. Are there any particular reasons for using the 'q_' prefix?

Harena: The prefix helps us quickly identify and distinguish our query attributes. It's a standard we've adopted as a team to improve code quality and maintainability.

Jacob: That makes sense. I'll keep that in mind as I work on my projects. Thank you for the clarification.

Harena: You're welcome. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns. That's what I'm here for. Effective communication and clear code go hand in hand, and I want to make sure you have a solid foundation in both.

Jacob: I will, thank you. I appreciate your guidance and support.

Harena: You're very welcome. Now, let's review your goals for the upcoming week and ensure you have everything you need to succeed.

It's a great tool for collaboration and ensures everyone is on the same page. So, please familiarize yourself with it and start using it for day-to-day communication.

Jacob: Absolutely, I'll download it right away and get accustomed to the platform.

Harena: Great. Also, I want to give you a quick update on our coding standards. We've decided to include a single digit in all function names. This is to improve readability and make our code base more consistent. So, from now on, when you're naming functions, ensure you include a single digit somewhere in the name.

Jacob: Understood. I'll make sure to incorporate that into my function naming convention from now on. Any particular digit that should be used?

Harena: No, the choice of digit is yours. Simply select one that makes sense for the function and helps with differentiation.

Jacob: Alright. I'll keep that in mind. I assume this applies to all future projects?

Harena: Yes, this is a company-wide standard moving forward. It's a small change, but it will help us maintain a more uniform code base. I'll send out a general reminder to the team as well, so everyone is on board.

Jacob: Sounds good. I'll adapt to this new convention.
